section.title: FORMATION AND USE OF TENSES IN FRENCH
section.para:
The present tense is used:
to describe an action happening at the moment you speak.
Je prends un livre et je lis. I take a book and I read.
to express usual actions occurring regularly.
Je me lève tous les matins à 6 heures. I get up every morning at 6 o'clock.
Il prend le train trois fois par semaine. He takes the train three times a week.
with some expressions of time, when the present action is near another future or past action:
Ils arrivent demain. They are arriving tomorrow.

listitem.para: to describe something that used to happen frequently or regularly in the past.

para.b: Quand j'étais jeune j'allais souvent à la piscine.
para.i: When I was young I often used to go to the swimming pool.

listitem.para: to describe something that lasted for a long period, when there is no indication of when it started or finished.

para.b: Nous habitions dans une petite maison.
para.i: We used to live in a little house.

listitem.para: in certain situations to describe a continuous action in relation to another action which is expressed in the perfect tense.

para.b: Que faisiez-vous quand l'accident est arrivé?
para.i: What were you doing when the accident happened?

listitem.para: to express a wish or make a suggestion.

para.b: Si on allait en ville ce soir?
para.i: How about going into town this evening?

para.b: Pendant que je dormais il faisait le ménage.
para.i: While I was sleeping he was doing the housework.

listitem.para: with depusi to describe how long an action had been going on.

para.i: I had been waiting for him/her for two hours.

section.title: The perfect
section.para: The perfect is a compound tense formed by the relevant form of the present tense of the auxiliary verb with the past participle. Avoir is used to form the compound tense of most verbs. Être is used to form the compound tenses of reflexive verbs (see ???) and for verbs of motion such as aller, arriver, descendre, devenir, entrer, monter, naître, partir, passer, rentrer, rester, retourner, sortir, tomber and venir. All the verbs in the verb list that take être rather than avoir are marked with an *.

listitem.para: to describe an action which is completed and which is no longer happening. It is the most commonly used of the past tenses.

para.i: I have bought a new car.

section.para: When used with the auxiliary être, past participles work in the same way as adjectives. They show gender (feminine or masculine) by adding -e if the subject is feminine; they show number (singular or plural) by adding -s if the subject is masculine plural, and -es for feminine plural:
Elles sont arrivées. (feminine, plural) They have arrived.
When used with the auxiliary avoir, the past participle agrees in number and gender with the direct object when the direct object comes before the participle and:

listitem.para: in a clause introduced by the relative pronoun que.
Les roses qu'elle a achetées. (feminine, plural) The roses (that) she has bought.
in a clause introduced by combien de..., quel, quelle, lequel and so on.
Combien de personnes avez-vous invitées? (feminine, plural) How many people have you invited?
when the pronoun is the direct object.
Je les ai vus hier soir. (masculine, plural) I saw them yesterday.

section.para: However, with the auxiliary avoir the past participle does not agree when the direct object is placed after the past participle.
If you are referring to the immediate past (i.e. to something you have just done) the past tense can be avoided by using venir de and the infinitive of the verb.

para.b: Je viens de finir mon travail.
para.i: I have just finished my work.
